title: Ticket #1587: Problems with semantics of failed file transfer
description:
Number 1 should be in V7_4-branch, all other stuff in master branch.

  1. it is a flat out bug that the ExitStatus, ExitSignal, and ExitedBySignal attributes are not set when file transfer fails. these attributes must be propagated into the job ad so the user can see them and make policy decisions using on_exit_hold and on_exit_remove. [DONE]

  2. the behavior of transfer_output_files will change so that a failure does not put the job on hold. (if the user desires this, they will be able to implement it using the on_exit_hold expression in the submit file... see items 3 and 4)

  3. each file that is successfully transferred is added to a list of "Good Files" in the job ad. each file that fails to transfer will be added to the list of "Bad Files" in the job ad.

  4. using these lists, users can specify what should happen when errors occur.

  5. if a file fails to be transferred for any reason other than not existing, the job will still go on hold as this is a system failure, not a problem with the job. in this case condor should increment NumSystemHolds for the job, which it currently does not.

to recreate the behavior we have today, you would simply add a line like this to the submit file: 

  on_exit_hold == (BadFilesList != "")

(that is, if there are any files in the bad files list, put the job on hold, which is what happens now)

Additional:

  1. The output files should be brought back smallest to largest first. If it is easy to specify an arbitrary ordering as well, then do it.
remarks:
2010-Aug-19 16:27:02 by psilord:
Ok, implementing number 1 in 7.4 correctly is a non-backwards compatible rathole. To implement it incorrectly would require a terrible hack that would be a nasty surprise for someone in the future and difficult to maintain.

The reason is that in JICShadow::transferOutput() when the file transfer fails (and it doesn't know if it is a critical error or recoverable error!), we call notifyStarterError() passing in the hold reason, hold code, hold subcode and enforcing that it is a critical error. This call ends up calling REMOTE_CONDOR_ulog() in the starter with the hold information.

When the shadow sees the critical hold request via the pseudo op ulog, it updates the job ad with the hold information from the network packet, updates the schedd with the new ad, then immediately exits with the JOB_SHOULD_HOLD code for the schedd. At this point there is no opportunity to inject the exit information of the job into the job ad.

One would think the correct way to fix this would be to implement a new pseudo call which simply updates whatever attributes in the sent ad into the job ad and commits it. Then I could call this just before notifyStarterError() and things would be happy. HOWEVER Doing this allows a race condition that if after the update from the starter to the shadow about the job exit status, then if the file transfer fails and both daemons are taken down, the schedd thinks the job completed successfully. Bad.

But, if this is in the stable series, then I can't change the protocol between the starter and the shadow. So, the nasty hack would be to encode the exit status of the job into the hold reason string, and decode it on the shadow side, if present, and insert the attributes into the job ad along with the hold attributes and continue. This probably still suffers from the race condition mentioned above if the shadow manages to update the jobad in the schedd and die badly before exiting with JOB_SHOULD_HOLD.

2010-Aug-19 16:29:54 by psilord:
Another bad idea would be to touch all of the output files at the job completion so the file transfer couldn't fail at all due to nonexistence. This is bad because if the job core dumped, we touch all of its files, then it would leave the queue totally. This is different behavior that what 1 implies. Which is the job still goes on hold, but the exit information is still injected into the ad.

2010-Aug-19 16:31:32 by psilord:
I'm going to explore making the file transfer failure a non-critical error and see what happens.

2010-Aug-19 16:42:32 by psilord:
I tried it and it won't work. ANY hold event from the starter to the shadow results in the shadow exiting ASAP.

2010-Aug-20 10:36:57 by psilord:
Ok, new tactic. I'm going to expand the interface to RemoteErrorEvent to include the exit information. Then, an updated starter and shadow can correctly serialize the exit information across the ulog pseduo call. For updated starters and old shadows, the old shadow will simply ignore the new information in the serialized classad instance of the RemoteErrorEvent and work as usual. This allows backwards compatibility in the stable series.

2010-Aug-20 14:11:22 by psilord:
Ok, expanding the interface wasn't a good idea.

I found REMOTE_CONDOR_set_job_attr() as a method of the starter setting job attrs in the jobad of the shadow. So I'm exploring that now.

2010-Aug-24 13:30:33 by psilord:
Ok, I have a different method, this one looks far better:

  1. In JICShadow::transferOutput(), decouple the handling of the failed transfer from the transfer itself. Put the handling of the failed transfer in to a new function called JICShadow::transferOutputMopUp().
  2. Add a new remote system call in NTsenders.cpp which transmits the exit status of the job over to the shadow which calls updateJob(U_TERMINATE) with the information. This sets the process specific termination attributes in the job ad, but this code path will not treat the job as having exited wrt terminate events in the job log, etc, etc, etc.
  3. In if JICShadow::transferOutput() fails, then if the shadow is of 7.4.4 or later, then send the new remote system call if the transfer failed due to the job having exited and not produced the whole of the transfer_output_files set. Then call JICShadow::transferOutputMopUp() which will notify the shadow of the failure and cause the shadow to drop the connection to the starter.

2010-Aug-26 11:26:42 by psilord:
Ok, the last proposal seems to be the right method. I've implemented the starter side, and am now just implementing the shadow side of what to do when it gets this termination information from the job.

Other than a nagging question of how to handle the list of jobs under the starter (like how do I know I picked the right job's exit status?) I think I'm on the downhill slide to completion.

2010-Aug-30 16:05:06 by psilord:
I can pick the right job out of the list by looking for the published ad from the user proc which contains ATTR_JOB_PID. All other jobs which are not the main job, like the pre/post scripts or condor_ssh, will name mangle that attribute name. A bit circuitous, but sufficient.

2010-Nov-01 15:34:26 by danb:
I think that the changes in commit b3ef6289 [18897] to improve handling of file transfer failures have somewhat broken disconnected shadow/starter handling.

The changes were intended to improve handling of the case where file transfer fails and wants to put the job on hold. However, there are other types of failures (such as network disconnect) where file transfer can fail without trying to put the job on hold. These cases used to be handled by the shadow/starter disconnect behavior. Now, the starter just blows up in an assert: 

11/01 14:58:57 Sandbox transfer failed.
11/01 14:58:57 ERROR "Assertion ERROR on (m_ft_info.hold_code != 0)" at line 435 in file jic_shadow.cpp

I see the following responsible code: 

if(!m_ft_info.success) {
   ASSERT(m_ft_info.hold_code != 0);
}

One way to test this code path is to SIGSTOP the shadow while the job is running. Then when the job finishes and the starter is blocked waiting for a response to its file transfer request, do condor_off -schedd. The desired behavior is that the starter sees the connection to the shadow go bad and enters disconnected mode. Turning the schedd back on should cause a new shadow to connect to the starter and successfully finish the file transfer. I have verified that this worked in 7.4.2.

I have made a child ticket #1750 for the disconnect bug.
